message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote on "constitutive character" for 德">
The author proposes a compromise: "constitutive character" for 德.

This combines:
- "Constitutive" (from chinese-phil-expert) — signals constructivism, neutral on innate/constructed, philosophical pedigree
- "Character" (from wittgenstein/existentialism/phil-mind) — avoids 性/nature collision, universal ("the character of water"), no moral baggage

Format: "constitutive character (德 De)" at first occurrence, then "constitutive character" in running text.

Quick vote: YES or NO? If no, say what's better in one sentence.
</teammate-message>

input.content: NO. Same running-text weight objection as "constitutive nature" -- seven syllables repeated eleven times in two paragraphs will bloat the densest passage in the collection. "Character" alone does the job; the TN establishes the constructivist dimension once.
input.summary: Votes NO on "constitutive character" — too heavy for running text

routing.summary: Votes NO on "constitutive character" — too heavy for running text
routing.content: NO. Same running-text weight objection as "constitutive nature" -- seven syllables repeated eleven times in two paragraphs will bloat the densest passage in the collection. "Character" alone does the job; the TN establishes the constructivist dimension once.

content.text: Voted NO on "constitutive character" -- same weight problem as "constitutive nature." Maintaining my position that plain "character" is the right choice.
